Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male cult member in ‘grotesque’ style. Head only. Bald, consistent with representations of priests or followers of Ptah or Harpocrates. Mould-made and hollow. Originally had festival wreath headdress added after this was removed from the mould, since lost. Mouth open, as if shouting or singing. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Gutch 1899, 95, no. 265). Number of examples found at Naukaris of this subject and style (Ashmolean AN1896-1908-G.101; AN1896-1908-G.100; AN1896-1908-E.4767, Fitzwilliam GR.18.1899; AN1896-1908-E.4767; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA522). Worshipper, possibly a priest of Harpocrates wearing headdress. 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels, particularly early 2nd century BC (Török 1995, pl.91, no.166 subject and pl.90, no. 164 style). Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 95, no. 265)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.522) (Phase 3)
